questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about the highlighted area?

choices.text: It consists of a superficial part and a deep part.
Excessive tensile forces cause avulsion fracture.
It's crossed by tibialis posterior and flexor digitorum longus.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Prone to injuries in eversion.

 

Explanation:

  • The ligament shown in the image is known as the deltoid ligament.
  • It is prone to injuries in inversion, not eversion.

 

Deltoid Ligament (Medial Ligament)

  • Location: Medial side of the ankle; triangular shape.
  • Structure: Divided into superficial and deep parts, both attached to the medial malleolus. (Option A)

Superficial Part:

  1. Anterior (Tibionavicular) Fibres:
    • Attachments: Tuberosity of navicular bone; medial margin of spring ligament.
  2. Middle (Tibiocalcanean) Fibres:
    • Attachments: Entire length of sustentaculum tali.
  3. Posterior (Tibiotalar) Fibres:
    • Attachments: Medial tubercle of posterior process of talus.

Deep Part:

  • Anterior Tibiotalar Fibres:
    • Attachments: Anterior part of the medial surface of the talus.
  • Characteristics:
    • Crossed by tendons of tibialis posterior and flexor digitorum longus (Option D).
    • Very strong; typically results in avulsion fracture rather than tear under excessive tensile forces (Option C).
    • Prone to injuries during inversion.

Lateral Ligament

  • Structure: Composed of three bands.
  1. Anterior Talofibular Ligament:
    • A flat band from anterior margin of lateral malleolus to neck of talus (in front of fibular facet).
  2. Posterior Talofibular Ligament:
    • Connects lower part of malleolar fossa of fibula to lateral tubercle of talus.
  3. Calcaneofibular Ligament:
    • Long rounded cord from notch on lower border of lateral malleolus to tubercle on lateral surface of calcaneus.
  • Characteristics:
    • Crossed by tendons of peroneus longus and brevis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman complains of difficulty adducting her toes. Which of the following muscles is primarily responsible for adducting the lateral three toes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Plantar interossei

 

Explanation:

The plantar interossei (fourth layer) are responsible for adducting the 3rd–5th toes (PAD – Plantar Adduct).

Third and fourth layers of the sole:

 

 

Adductor hallucis (Option A) adducts the great toe at the metatarsophalangeal joint.

 

The dorsal interossei (Option B) (fourth layer) performs abduction of the toes (DAB – Dorsal Abduct), not adduction.

 

Adductor digitorum brevis (Option D) does not exist.

questions.text: A 30-year-old athlete complains of difficulty in flexion at the metatarsophalangeal joint and extension at the interphalangeal joint of the second toe. Which of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: First lumbrical is affected and is supplied by the lateral plantar nerve.
First lumbrical is affected and is supplied by the medial plantar nerve.
Second lumbrical is affected and is supplied by the lateral plantar nerve.
Second lumbrical is affected and is supplied by the medial plantar nerve.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) First lumbrical is affected and is supplied by the medial plantar nerve.

 

Explanation:

The first lumbrical, which acts on the second toe, is supplied by the medial plantar nerve.

 

  • It facilitates flexion at the metatarsophalangeal joint and extension at the interphalangeal joints.
  • The lumbricals of the foot show a pattern of dual innervation:
  • The medial plantar nerve innervates the first lumbrical.
  • The second, third, and fourth lumbricals are innervated by the lateral plantar nerve.
  • This distribution mirrors the innervation seen in the hand, where a division between median and ulnar nerve innervation exists.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with complaints of claudication and cramping pain in his left lower limb while walking short distances, which is relieved by rest. On further examination, his left dorsalis pedis pulse is diminished, and he has cool skin on the affected leg. Doppler ultrasound reveals significant atherosclerosis at the bifurcation of the common iliac artery. Which of the following arteries, if most affected by this condition, is likely responsible for the reduced blood flow to his lower limb?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) External iliac artery

 

Explanation:

External iliac artery is the primary artery that continues as the femoral artery to supply the lower limb.

  • Atherosclerosis at the bifurcation of the common iliac artery directly affects the external iliac artery, reducing blood flow to the entire lower limb, causing claudication.

  • The internal iliac artery primarily supplies the pelvis and perineum.
  • The internal pudendal artery a branch of the internal iliac artery, supplies the genitalia and perineum, not the lower limb.
  • The inferior epigastric artery, a branch of the external iliac artery, supplies the anterior abdominal wall, not the lower limb.

 

Reference:

questions.text: During surgery for a femoral shaft fracture, the surgeon notes damage to the vastus lateralis muscle. Which artery is primarily responsible for supplying the vastus lateralis?

choices.text: Ascending branch of femoral circumflex artery
Ascending branch of medial femoral circumflex artery
Descending branch of lateral femoral circumflex artery
Transverse branch if medial femoral circumflex artery

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Descending branch of the lateral femoral circumflex artery

 

Explanation:

The descending branch of the lateral femoral circumflex artery supplies the vastus lateralis muscle as it descends along its anterior border.

Medial and Lateral Femoral Circumflex Arteries

  • Branches of the profunda femoris artery (from the femoral artery)
  • Main blood supply to adductor, extensor, and flexor thigh muscles
  • Anastomose with internal/external iliac arteries (superior) and popliteal artery (inferior)

Lateral Femoral Circumflex Artery

  • Branches near the root of profunda femoris, run laterally
  • Divides into ascending, descending, and transverse branches

Branches:

Branch

Course

Function/Anastomosis

Ascending (Option A)

Ascends along intertrochanteric line, under tensor fasciae latae

Supplies greater trochanter, forms anastomotic ring around femoral neck (with medial femoral circumflex artery)

Descending (Option C)

Descends posterior to rectus femoris, along anterior vastus lateralis

Supplies vastus lateralis, anastomoses with superior lateral genicular artery (at knee)

Transverse

Passes laterally, anterior to vastus intermedius, pierces vastus lateralis near greater trochanter

Forms cruciate anastomosis (with medial femoral circumflex, inferior gluteal, and first perforating arteries)

Medial Femoral Circumflex Artery

  • Typically branches from profunda femoris, sometimes from the femoral artery
  • Supplies adductor muscles, runs medially around femur

Branches:

Branch

Course

Function/Anastomosis

Transverse (Option D)

Runs near quadratus femoris

Contributes to cruciate anastomosis

Ascending (Option B)

Ascends on obturator externus tendon, reaches trochanteric fossa

Anastomoses with gluteal and lateral femoral circumflex arteries, supplies hip joint via the acetabular branch.

Anastomoses:

Anastomosis

Location

Involved Arteries

Trochanteric anastomosis

Trochanteric fossa

Ascending branch of medial femoral circumflex, superior/inferior gluteal arteries, lateral femoral circumflex, first perforating artery

Cruciate anastomosis

Lesser trochanter (inferior)

Transverse branches of medial and lateral femoral circumflex, inferior gluteal artery, first perforating artery

questions.text: A patient is experiencing discomfort in the lower limb due to venous insufficiency. Which of the following mechanisms aid in the venous return of blood from the lower limb to the heart?

choices.text: Contraction of calf muscles leads to compression of superficial veins

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Deep fascia limits muscle expansion

 

Explanation:

The deep fascia enhances the muscle pump by limiting outward muscle expansion, helping direct blood flow upwards through deep veins.

Venous Drainage of the Lower Limb

  • The venous system of the lower limb returns deoxygenated blood to the heart.
  • Key aspects include vein groups, connections, and clinical significance.

Groups of Veins

  • Superficial Veins: Located in subcutaneous tissue, above the deep fascia.
  • Deep Veins: Positioned deep to the fascia, accompany major arteries, and are more numerous than superficial veins.

Important Superficial Veins

Vein Type

Description

Great Saphenous

Longest vein in the body; originates on the medial foot, ascends along the medial leg and thigh to the femoral vein; significant for venous return and surgical grafts.

Small Saphenous

Originates on the lateral foot, ascends posteriorly along the leg, drains into the popliteal vein in the fossa.

Perforating Veins

  • Connect superficial and deep venous systems.
  • Contain valves for unidirectional blood flow, preventing backflow.

Factors Aiding Venous Return

  • Valves: Ensure unidirectional flow towards the heart.
  • Muscle Pump: Calf muscle contraction compresses deep veins, aiding blood propulsion. (Option B)
  • Deep Fascia: Limits muscle expansion, enhancing pressure on deep veins during contraction. (Option A)
  • Negative Intrathoracic Pressure: Assists in drawing blood upwards during inspiration. (Option C)

Clinical Significance: Varicose Veins

  • Definition: Enlarged, twisted veins caused by incompetent valves allowing backward blood flow, leading to dilation.
  • Contributing Factors:
    • Malfunctioning valves, causing blood to backflow, pool, and lead to dilation.
    • Incompetent perforating veins allow high-pressure deep blood to flow into the superficial system, exacerbating varicosity.

Vasodilation of superficial veins (Option D): Vasodilation would increase venous pressure and contribute to venous insufficiency, not aid in venous return.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to the emergency department with a swollen right leg and pain following a long-haul flight. Doppler ultrasound confirms a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the right calf. Which statement about the anatomy of the deep veins of the lower limb is correct?

choices.text: The anterior tibial vein runs alongside the fibular artery.
The medial and lateral plantar veins contribute to the formation of the popliteal vein.
Perforating veins carry blood from deep veins to superficial veins.
The fibular veins drain directly into the femoral vein.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The medial and lateral plantar veins contribute to the formation of the popliteal vein.

 

Explanation:

The medial and lateral plantar veins unite to form the posterior tibial veins, which then contribute to the formation of the popliteal vein.

Deep Veins of the Lower Limb

  • Deep veins are located beneath the deep fascia of the lower limb, running alongside major arteries and are more numerous than superficial veins.
  • They generally share names with their accompanying arteries and follow similar paths.

Characteristics:

Feature

Description

Connections

Receive blood from superficial veins via perforating veins equipped with valves for unidirectional flow.

Venous Return Role

Critical for returning blood to the heart; compression during muscle contraction (especially calf muscles) propels blood upward (muscle pump).

Clinical Significance

Important in conditions like Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) and potential complications such as pulmonary embolism.

Specific Deep Veins:

Vein

Description

Plantar Digital Veins

Originate in toes, contributing to plantar metatarsal veins.

Plantar Metatarsal Veins

Run in intermetatarsal spaces, connecting with dorsal veins via perforating veins.

Deep Plantar Venous Arch

Formed by plantar metatarsal veins; gives rise to medial and lateral plantar veins.

Medial & Lateral Plantar Veins

Course alongside corresponding arteries; contribute to posterior tibial veins. They contribute to the formation of the popliteal vein. (Option B)

Posterior Tibial Veins

Formed behind the medial malleolus by the union of medial and lateral plantar veins.

Anterior Tibial Veins

Accompany the anterior tibial artery.

Fibular Veins

Run alongside the fibular artery.

Popliteal Vein

Formed by the union of anterior and posterior tibial veins and the fibular vein; ascends to become femoral vein.

Femoral Vein

Main deep vein of the thigh; receives blood from popliteal vein, profunda femoris vein, and long saphenous vein.

Profunda Femoris Vein

Drains deep structures of the thigh; merges with the femoral vein.

Conditions:

  • Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): Formation of a thrombus in deep veins, often in the calf due to sluggish blood flow.
  • Pulmonary Embolism: Thrombus fragments can dislodge, travel to the lungs, and cause a life-threatening blockage.

The anterior tibial vein runs alongside the fibular artery (Option A): The anterior tibial vein runs alongside the anterior tibial artery.

Perforating veins carry blood from deep veins to superficial veins (Option C): Perforating veins allow blood to flow from superficial veins to deep veins.

The fibular veins drain directly into the femoral vein. (Option D): The fibular veins drain into the popliteal vein, not directly into the femoral vein.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with symptoms of heaviness and visible varicose veins primarily affecting her left leg. Duplex ultrasonography reveals dilation of the great saphenous vein (GSV) with incompetent valves. She is scheduled for vein stripping surgery. Which of the following statements regarding the anatomical features of the GSV compared to the small saphenous vein (SSV) is correct?

choices.text: The GSV has fewer valves than the SSV, making it less prone to varicosities
The GSV originates from the lateral end of the dorsal venous arch of the foot
The GSV is a continuation of the medial marginal vein.
The GSV pierces the deep fascia to drain into the popliteal vein.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The GSV is a continuation of the medial marginal vein

 

Explanation:

The GSV arises from the medial marginal vein on the dorsum of the foot.

Superficial Veins of the Lower Limb

  • Superficial veins are located in the subcutaneous tissue, above the deep fascia
  • They drain blood from superficial lower limb tissues
  • Important superficial veins: Great Saphenous Vein (GSV) and Small Saphenous Vein (SSV)

Great Saphenous Vein (GSV)

Feature

Description

Origin

Arises on the dorsum of the foot, as a continuation of the medial marginal vein (Option C)

Course
  • Ascends in front of the medial malleolus
  • Runs along the medial leg
  • Courses behind the knee
  • Inclines forward in the thigh
  • Passes through the saphenous opening into the femoral vein

Tributaries
  • Dorsal venous arch of the foot
  • Medial marginal vein
  • Posterior arch vein
  • Calf vein
  • Accessory saphenous vein
  • Anterior cutaneous vein of the thigh
  • Superficial epigastric, circumflex iliac, and external pudendal veins

Valves

Contains 10-20 valves, more concentrated in the leg (Option A)

Clinical Significance

Commonly used in surgical grafting, especially for coronary artery bypass

 

Small Saphenous Vein (SSV)

Feature

Description

Origin

Forms on the dorsum of the foot from the lateral dorsal venous arch (Option B)

Course
  • Ascends behind the lateral malleolus
  • Runs along the calf
  • Drains into the popliteal vein after piercing the deep fascia (Option D)

Tributaries

Receives cutaneous tributaries from the lateral foot, heel, and back of the leg

Connections

Communicates with deep veins and connects with GSV through branches

Valves

Contains 7-13 valves, with one near its termination

Termination Variability

May join GSV, bifurcate, or drain into other veins

 

Clinical Relevance

  • Varicose Veins: Dilated, tortuous veins due to valve incompetence, commonly in GSV and tributaries

Venous Return: Superficial veins aid blood return to the heart via muscle pump mechanism, facilitated by valves in perforating veins

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with burning pain and tingling in the plantar aspect of her foot. She reports that the symptoms worsen with prolonged standing and improve with rest. You tap over the region just behind the medial malleolus, and the patient experiences tingling and numbness radiating into the sole of her foot. The underlying cause of her symptoms is likely related to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Compressive Neuropathy

 

Explanation:

  • The presentation is consistent with tarsal tunnel syndrome
  • The underlying cause is compressive neuropathy, compression of the tibial nerve as it passes through the tarsal tunnel.

Tarsal Tunnel Syndrome

Definition: Compressive neuropathy of the tibial nerve at the tarsal tunnel.

  • Symptoms
    • Pain with prolonged standing or walking.
    • Vague, misleading medial foot pain.
    • Sharp, burning pain in the foot.
    • Numbness and intermittent paresthesias in the plantar foot.
  • P/E
    • Tinel’s test of the ankle is performed by tapping the tibial nerve directly over the flexor retinaculum posterior to the medial malleolus.
    • The test is considered positive (Tinel’s sign) if the patient reports paresthesia or numbness in the distribution of the tibial nerve or its branches. (Option A, C, and D)
    • Pain with ankle dorsiflexion and eversion.
    • Compression test: pain with plantar flexion and inversion, digital pressure over the tarsal tunnel (highly sensitive and specific).

Investigation:

  • Radiographs

    • Weight-bearing radiographs to assess osseous structures.

  • MRI

    • Helpful to rule out accessory muscle or soft-tissue tumours.

Treatment

  • Nonoperative
    • Lifestyle Modifications: Changes in activity to reduce symptoms.
    • Medications:
      • Anti-inflammatory medications.
      • SSRIs have been used in some cases.
    • Bracing/Orthosis: Footwear changes to address hindfoot alignment.
    • Casting: Short-leg cast is an option.
  • Operative
    • Indications for Surgery:
      • Failed conservative management for 3-6 months.
      • Identified compressive mass (e.g., ganglion cyst).
      • Positive EMG findings.
      • Reproducible physical findings.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with difficulty wearing shoes and discomfort in her toes. She reports pain in the forefoot and has noticed that the tips of her toes frequently press into the ground while walking. On physical examination, the toes are bent at the middle and distal joints, with hyperextension at the base. The deformity worsens when wearing tight shoes. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the description of the deformity?.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Claw toe

 

Explanation:

  • The given image is of a claw toe, a lesser toe deformity
  • Characterised by hyperextension of the MTP joint, along with flexion at the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) and distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints.

Claw Toe

 

  • Definition: Lesser toe deformity with MTP hyperextension and PIP/DIP flexion.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Clinical evaluation showing:
      • MTP hyperextension
      • PIP flexion
      • DIP flexion
  • Treatment:
    • Nonoperative Management:
      • Shoe modifications
      • Taping
    • Surgical Management:
      • Indicated for:
        • Progressive deformity
        • Fixed contractures
        • Dorsal toe ulcerations

Other toe deformities: (Option B, C and D)

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a fall from a height. He complains of severe pain in the heel and inability to bear weight on his foot. On physical examination, there is swelling and tenderness at the heel. Which bone is most likely affected?.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Calcaneus

 

Explanation:

  • The calcaneus is the largest tarsal bone located in the heel and is the most commonly fractured tarsal bone following a fall from height.


Bone Group

Bones

Description & Function

Tarsals

  

Provide mechanical support and structure to the foot.

Proximal Group

Talus
  • Transmits body weight to the foot.
  • Articulates at three joints:
  • Superiorly: Ankle joint (tibia/fibula)
  • Inferiorly: Subtalar joint (calcaneus)
  • Anteriorly: Talonavicular joint (navicular)

Calcaneus
  • Largest tarsal bone, forms the heel.
  • Articulates at two joints:
  • Superiorly: Subtalar joint (talus)
  • Anteriorly: Calcaneocuboid joint (cuboid)

Intermediate Group

Navicular
  • Boat-shaped; articulates with talus, cuneiforms, and cuboid.
  • Has a tuberosity for tibialis posterior tendon attachment.

Distal Group

Cuboid
  • Lateral; articulates with calcaneus and fourth/fifth metatarsals.
  • Features a groove for the fibularis longus tendon.

Cuneiforms (3)
  • Medial, intermediate, lateral; wedge-shaped.
  • Help form the transverse arch; attach to various muscles.

Metatarsals

I-V (1-5)
  • Connect tarsals to phalanges; numbered medial to lateral.
  • Have a head, neck, shaft, and base; facilitate movement and support.

Phalanges

Great Toe: 2 (proximal, distal)
  • Toes 2-5: 3 each (proximal, intermediate, distal).
  • Each phalanx has a base, shaft, and head, providing structure to toes.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male marathon runner presents with complaints of foot pain after long-distance runs. On examination, the foot shows a well-formed arch, and palpation reveals tenderness along the medial aspect of the foot. An X-ray confirms a normal medial longitudinal arch structure. Which of the following statements incorrectly describes the function or anatomy of the medial longitudinal arch in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Has limited mobility

 

Explanation:

  • The given image is of the medial arch
  • The medial arch is more mobile and resilient, allowing it to function effectively as a shock absorber.

 

Feature

Medial Longitudinal Arch

Lateral Longitudinal Arch

Height

Higher

Lower

Mobility

More mobile, resilient

Limited mobility, more rigid

Shock Absorption

Functions as a shock absorber(Option A rule out)

Transmits weight

Anterior End

Heads of 1st, 2nd, 3rd metatarsals

Heads of 4th, 5th metatarsals

Posterior End

Medial tubercle of calcaneum

Lateral tubercle of calcaneum

Summit

Superior articular surface of the talus

Articular facet on the superior surface of calcaneum (at the subtalar joint)

Anterior Pillar

Talus, navicular, 3 cuneiforms, 1–3 metatarsals

Cuboid and 4th, 5th metatarsals

Posterior Pillar

Medial half of calcaneum

Lateral half of calcaneum

Main Joint

  

Talocalcaneonavicular joint(Option D rule out)

Calcaneocuboid joint

Bony Key Stone

Head of talus(Option B rule out)

Cuboid

Intersegmental Ties

Spring ligament (Plantar calcaneo navicular ligament)

Long plantar ligament, Short plantar ligament

Tie Beams

Medial part of plantar aponeurosis, Abductor hallucis, Medial part of flexor digitorum brevis

Lateral part of plantar aponeurosis, Abductor digiti minimi, Lateral part of flexor digitorum brevis

Slings

Tibialis posterior, Flexor hallucis longus

Peroneus longus, Peroneus brevis, Flexor digitorum longus

Suspension Sling

Tibialis anterior and peroneus longus

Tibialis anterior and peroneus longus

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with difficulty in flexing the lateral four toes. On examination, it is noted that the action of the flexor digitorum longus tendon is intact. Which of the following muscles, in the second layer of the sole, assists the flexor digitorum longus during this action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Quadratus plantae

 

Explanation:

The quadratus plantae in the second layer of the sole, assists the flexor digitorum longus by helping align and pull its tendon straight, thereby aiding in the flexion of the lateral four toes.

First and Second layers of the sole:

 

 

 

 

The abductor hallucis (Option A) (first layer) is involved in abducting the big toe.

 

The flexor digitorum brevis (Option B) (first layer) also flexes the lateral four toes but acts more proximally at the middle phalanges and does not assist the action of flexor digitorum longus.

 

The lumbricals (Option D) (second layer) are primarily involved in flexing the metatarsophalangeal joints and extending the interphalangeal joints, not in pure flexion.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a deep laceration on the posterior aspect of his knee after a road traffic accident. On surgical exploration, the popliteal artery is injured. Which of the following is not a direct branch of the popliteal artery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Fibular artery

 

Explanation:

The fibular (peroneal) artery is a branch of the posterior tibial artery, not a direct branch of the popliteal artery.

 

Branches of the Popliteal Artery

Branch

Supply

Muscular branches

Supply the adductor magnus and hamstrings, gastrocnemius, soleus, and plantaris.

Cutaneous branches

Arise from the popliteal artery or indirectly from its muscular branches.

Genicular branches:

Five branches in total: two superior, two inferior, one middle.

Middle genicular artery

Pierces the oblique popliteal ligament, supplies cruciate ligaments and synovial membrane of the knee.

Medial and lateral superior genicular arteries (Option A)

Wind around the femur above the condyles, pass deep to the hamstrings.

Medial and lateral inferior genicular arteries

Wind around the tibial condyles, pass deep to the collateral ligaments of the knee, form anastomoses around the knee.

Terminal Branches:

It terminates at the lower border of popliteus by dividing into the anterior (Option C) and posterior tibial arteries (Option B)

questions.text: During a surgical procedure involving the reconstruction of the lower limb, the surgeon plans to use a perforator flap. Which of the following statements about perforating arteries is correct?

choices.text: Perforating arteries are exclusively found in the thigh region.
Musculocutaneous perforators run along intermuscular septa before supplying the skin.
Perforating arteries can originate from major source arteries or adjacent vessels and are essential for flap surgery.
Septocutaneous perforators only supply the periosteum of bones.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Perforating arteries can originate from major source arteries or adjacent vessels and are essential for flap surgery.

 

Explanation:

  • Perforating arteries play a significant role in reconstructive flap surgeries as they can originate from major source arteries (e.g., femoral artery) or from vessels in adjacent tissues.
  • This versatility is critical for ensuring adequate blood supply to the flap, which is necessary for successful healing and function.

Perforating Veins and Arteries in the Lower Limb

Perforating Veins: Connecting Venous Systems

  • Function: Essential for venous return; connect superficial veins (e.g., great and small saphenous veins) to deep veins (e.g., femoral, popliteal, tibial veins).
  • Valve Role: Valves ensure one-way blood flow from superficial to deep veins, preventing backflow and enhancing venous return.
  • Classification:
    • Direct Perforating Veins: Direct connections between superficial and deep veins.
    • Examples:
      • Great and Small Saphenous Veins: Major direct perforators.
      • Small Direct Perforators:
        • Thigh: Adductor canal perforator connects great saphenous vein to femoral vein.
        • Below the Knee: Perforator links great saphenous vein to posterior tibial vein.
        • Leg: Lateral perforator joins small saphenous vein to peroneal vein; medial perforators link posterior arch vein to posterior tibial vein.
    • Indirect Perforating Veins: Connect through muscular veins before reaching deep veins.
  • Clinical Significance:
    • Valve Incompetence: Faulty valves can cause varicose veins by allowing backflow from deep to superficial veins.
    • Post-Thrombotic Incompetence: Following DVT, perforating veins may reopen without functioning valves, leading to chronic venous insufficiency.

 

 

Perforating Arteries: Blood Supply to Lower Limb Tissues

  • Definition: Arteries that penetrate deep fascia to supply the suprafascial plexus (blood vessel network in subcutaneous tissue).
  • Types:
    • Direct Cutaneous Perforator: Supplies skin directly from source artery.
    • Periosteocutaneous Perforator: Supplies skin after traveling along a bone.
    • Musculocutaneous Perforator: Passes through muscle before reaching the skin.
    • Septocutaneous Perforator: Runs along an intermuscular septum to supply skin.
    • Other Types: Include neurocutaneous, tendocutaneous, venocutaneous, and intercompartmental perforators.
  • Clinical Importance:
    • Flap Surgery: Perforator flaps are used for wound coverage and reconstruction, supplied by perforating arteries.
    • Donor Site: Lower limbs have an average of 90 perforating arteries, making them key for flap procedures.

Applications of Perforator Flaps

Region

Application

Gluteal Region

Breast reconstruction; covering sacral/perineal defects

Hip and Thigh

Versatile flaps from anterolateral, anteromedial thighs, TFL for various reconstructions

Knee and Leg

Useful for knee and lower leg defects; posterior tibial artery flaps critical for reconstructions

Ankle and Foot

Local skin flaps preferred due to specialized skin structure

 

Perforating arteries are exclusively found in the thigh region (Option A): Perforating arteries are found throughout the lower limb, not exclusively in the thigh.

 

Musculocutaneous perforators run along intermuscular septa before supplying the skin (Option B): Musculocutaneous perforators pass through muscles before reaching the skin, not along intermuscular septa.

Septocutaneous perforators only supply the periosteum of bones (Option D): Septocutaneous perforators supply the skin after traveling along intermuscular septa.
